text:p.text:span: Second person; labialisation of the initial consonant of Class 3 verbs beginning with gg, and Class 1 verbs beginning with k or g. Also of the Potential mode prefix for Class 2 verbs.
to struggle, try hard, to struggle to climb out of something, as a hole.
He tried hard looking for a way to get out.
Luḳ waaḳ lom waain rot rëḳ ma menedo loḳ.
He fell into the cave and he struggled hard to get out but he couldn't and he had to remain there.
There's a huge cave in the bush.
grew up and broke the yam stake.
a kind of green vegetable from the coast, the vine is used for tying boats because it doesn't rot quickly in the sea.
Waing og yiḳ jojeng nivesa ti sën hil ġeyeh maġa.
is a good kind of green vegetable which we cook and eat.
bananas and carried them to the house.
to crackle, as when crushing something dry or brittle; to dry up in the sun.
Nyëġ raḳ aru berus beyö warak warak.
The sun shone on the tobacco leaves and they crackled (when crushed).
to bolt, to eat quickly, to do something hastily/quickly, to hurry, to go in haste.
Vuu huk geneya warwar in detahi yi ggëp begganġ.
He left the garden and went quickly because they had called him from the village.
stalks of reed trailing in the water and moving back and forth with the current.
The reeds were bobbing around in the water.
Newa ggee nebë bël neḳo warwid.
His heart was leaping about like a reed bobbing in the water.
Spit it out! (Often said to small children)
He didn't like what he heard and spat out, "
The reeds grew at the base of the fence.
He cut the reeds and used them to make a fence.
Wes kevoh gebegganġ neggëp nyë tale.
The wall collapsed and the house was left standing open.
Ham ḳo mun wëëj loḳ sapu.
You caught a great many rats in the snares.
There are a great many of us, more than of them.
variety of bamboo which grows in the bush. It is used for stringing bows, making the saw for making fires, etc,.
Wëëk nam sena ġaḳo bël doḳ.
Give me the bamboo, I'll go and get water in it.
He split the wëëk bamboo and strung his bow with it.
a block of land, the area of ground a person looks after.
Amaġ lo yö hir wëh sën yö debë taġee loḳ.
This is my fathers' piece of ground where they planted highland pandanus.
the village of Wij, also known as Davonġ.
Wirek alam degelu sir raḳ ruġ.
In the old days people speared each other with spears.
earlier, old, pertaining to or belonging to an earlier time.
Su wirek hen gaḳ yiḳ sëë nahën-ë.
It wasn't a long time ago, it just happened recently.
from long ago, many times in the past, for a long time.
Hil aha nos wirek wirek beverup gwëbeng sënë.
We have eaten food from way back and right up to the present.
Ġeya ġenedo bebuum wirek wirek om ġenom begganġ.
You have been living with the whiteman for a very long time, so come back to the village.
Cook the eel by wrapping it in
alas, exclamation of concern, anxiety, or pity.
Wöp-o! Sa kwaġ virek in vasöl.
Oh dear! I have forgotten the bow.
Sa in-a! Wöp-o, sëḳ na menoh tena in dekepa aggata.
What will I do! Oh dear, where will I go, they have blocked off the road.
